entry.title: Deployment Error DEP_2017 in SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
I went through https://trials.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/learning-journey/BT-SBPA . When selecting a released version of my implementation, i'm getting the error message DEP_2017.

 

After closing the popup, i can select 'Deploy', but the next popup to select the environment, is not responding at all...

Any help is highly appreciated!

entry.title: How to get visible rows count in SAP Webgui grid view in SAP Build ProcessAutomation task automation
entry.content:
Hi,

I am building a task automation where bot has to assign settlement rule for each service order item in 'Manage Settlement Rule - Service Documents' app in S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

This is a Webgui screen and I can't find any suitable activity that may provide the visible rows count as it is available in SAP GUI irpa SDK.

I also checked this blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-intelligent-robotic-process-automation-2-0-sap-gui-table-control-2-2/ba-p/13507394 where it mentions about 'Get Scroll Max (GUI Table)' for a SAP GUI table control. But I couldn't find any equivalent activity corresponding to Webgui grid view. 

I understand that for grid view I have to use activity 'Scroll Vertically (WebGUI Grid View)' to allow the bot scroll down to make new rows visible based on the number of service order items. But I need to know how many rows are visible or how many max rows possible to determine when and how many times bot has to scroll down till all the items are worked upon.

@peterengel 

Best regards,

Sumit

entry.title: Manual Export/Import vs Cloud Transport Management Service to transport BTP projects
entry.content:
Hi experts, 

I'm confusing which method is better between manual export/import and Cloud Transport Management Service to transport BTP projects like Build Process Automation approval workflows, Business Application Studio ui5 apps and Integration Suite iflows.

I checked some blogs and it is recommended to use Cloud Transport Management Service instead manual export/import.

By using Cloud Transport Management Service, there are advantages like Manual effort (no need to reconfigure everything), Less error-prone and so on.

So, I tried to transport one of my BPA approval process by using both methods.

And the results are same.

I needed to reconfigure the same steps for both methods.

There is no difference between them and using cTMS is more complex for me because there is initial set up and additional cost too.

 

So, could you please explain details why and when cTMS should be used, in details?

 

Thank You.

Aye Chan

entry.title: Automating SAP HANA System Startup in a Distributed HANA Environment on GCP
entry.content:
Overview

In a distributed SAP HANA environment hosted on Google Cloud Platform (GCP), starting SAP systems after a VM reboot can often be a manual and time-consuming process.
By creating automation scripts and integrating them with systemd services, we can ensure that both the HANA database and SAP application servers start automatically when the VM is powered on from the GCP Console — without manual intervention.

This guide explains how we implemented and tested an automated startup sequence with detailed logging for monitoring.

Architecture

Our distributed SAP HANA setup consists of:

  • Database Node – runs the HANA database
  • Application Node – runs SAP ASCS and SAP Application Server

The goal:

  • Start the HANA DB automatically when the DB VM boots.
  • Wait until the DB is online before starting the SAP ASCS and App instances.
  • Maintain detailed logs for troubleshooting .

1. HANA DB Auto Start Script

File: /usr/local/bin/start_hana_db.sh
Purpose: Start the HANA DB service and log every step.

#!/bin/bash

LOGFILE="/usr/sap/<SID>/start_hana_db.log"
echo "=== Starting HANA DB at $(date) ===" >> "$LOGFILE"

# Step 1: StartService
echo "Running StartService..." >> "$LOGFILE"
/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartService <DB_SID> >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1

# Wait for 10 seconds
echo "Sleeping for 10 seconds..." >> "$LOGFILE"
sleep 10

# Step 2: Start DB
echo "Starting HANA DB..." >> "$LOGFILE"
/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function Start >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1

echo "=== HANA DB Startup Complete at $(date) ===" >> "$LOGFILE"

2. systemd Service Units

Database Node Service (hana_start.service): 

[Unit]
Description=Start SAP HANA DB via sapcontrol
After=network-online.target multi-user.target
Wants=network-online.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=<hana_admin_user>
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/start_hana_db.sh
TimeoutStartSec=300
RemainAfterExit=yes

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

3. Enabling the Services

On Database Node:

sudo systemctl daemon-reexec
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable hana_start.service
sudo systemctl start hana_start.service
sudo systemctl status hana_start.service

4. SAP App Auto Start Script

File: /usr/local/bin/start_sap_after_db.sh
Purpose: Wait for HANA DB availability before starting SAP ASCS and App instances.

#!/bin/bash

LOGFILE="/usr/sap/<SID>/sap_app_startup.log"

echo "===== SAP Application Startup Script Triggered at $(date) =====" >> "$LOGFILE"

echo "Checking if SAP application can connect to HANA DB using R3trans -d..." >> "$LOGFILE"

# Wait until SAP can connect to DB
while true; do
    su - <sap_admin_user> -c 'R3trans -d' >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
    if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
        echo "$(date): SAP Application can connect to DB. Proceeding with startup." >> "$LOGFILE"
        break
    else
        echo "$(date): R3trans -d failed. Waiting 10s before retrying..." >> "$LOGFILE"
        sleep 10
    fi
done

# Start ASCS instance
echo "$(date): Starting SAP ASCS Instance..." >> "$LOGFILE"
su - <sap_admin_user> -c '/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr <ASCS_Instance_Number> -function Start' >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1

sleep 10

# Start App Server instance
echo "$(date): Starting SAP App Server Instance..." >> "$LOGFILE"
su - <sap_admin_user> -c '/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr <App_Instance_Number> -function Start' >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1

echo "$(date): SAP ASCS and App Server started successfully." >> "$LOGFILE"

5. systemd Service Units

Application Node Service (sapapp_start.service):

[Unit]
Description=Start SAP Application After HANA DB is Ready
After=network-online.target
Wants=network-online.target

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/start_sap_after_db.sh
RemainAfterExit=yes

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

6. Enabling the Services

On Application Node:

chmod +x /usr/local/bin/start_sap_after_db.sh
sudo systemctl daemon-reexec
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable sapapp_start.service
systemctl start sapapp_start.service

7. Monitoring and Logs

  • DB Startup Logs: /usr/sap/<DB_SID>/start_hana_db.log

  • App Startup Logs: /usr/sap/<APP_SID>/sap_startup.log

6. Benefits of this Setup

  • Zero manual intervention after VM boot from GCP Console
  • Timestamped logs for debugging 
  • DB starts first, App waits until DB is ready

Conclusion

With this setup:

  • SAP HANA and application layers start automatically on reboot.
  • Logging is comprehensive, timestamped,
  • Startup sequence is well-coordinated — DB first, then App components.

This reduces manual work and enhances resilience for SAP environments running on GCP or similar platforms.

Regards,

Nitin Khose

entry.title: Automatically Start Sybase Database and SAP Application on the Same Host
entry.content:
Overview

In many SAP landscapes, the Sybase database and SAP application run on the same host. By creating automation scripts and integrating them with systemd services, we can ensure both the Sybase database and SAP application start automatically whenever the VM is powered on from the GCP Console — without any manual intervention.

Architecture

Since the database and application are hosted on the same server, the sequence is straightforward:

  • Start the Sybase database (dataserver and backup server)
  • Wait for the database to be fully online
  • Start the SAP application

1. Sybase + SAP Application Auto Start Script

File: /usr/local/bin/start_sybase_sap.sh
Purpose: Start Sybase dataserver, Sybase backup server, and SAP application in sequence.

#!/bin/csh

# Set environment
unsetenv LANG
setenv LANG us_english.utf8

cd /sybase/<SYBASE_DIR>
source SYBASE.csh

# Log file
set LOGFILE="/usr/sap/start_sybase_sap.log"

echo "===== Starting Sybase and SAP at `date` =====" >>& $LOGFILE

# Start dataserver
echo "Starting Sybase dataserver..." >>& $LOGFILE
$SYBASE/$SYBASE_ASE/install/RUN_<DB_NAME> >>& $LOGFILE &

sleep 120  # Wait 2 minutes for dataserver to initialize

# Check if dataserver is running
ps -ef | grep "dataserver" | grep "\-s<DB_NAME>" | grep -v grep > /dev/null
if ($status != 0) then
    echo "Error: dataserver did not start successfully." >>& $LOGFILE
    exit 1
endif

# Start backup server
echo "Starting Sybase backup server..." >>& $LOGFILE
$SYBASE/$SYBASE_ASE/install/RUN_<BACKUP_NAME> >>& $LOGFILE &

sleep 30

# Start SAP application
echo "Switching to SAP admin user to start SAP..." >>& $LOGFILE
su - <SAP_ADMIN_USER> -c 'startsap R3' >>& $LOGFILE

echo "===== Finished at `date` =====" >>& $LOGFILE
exit 0

4. systemd Service Unit

File: /etc/systemd/system/sybase_sap_start.service
Purpose: Run the startup script automatically at boot.

[Unit]
Description=Start Sybase and SAP Automatically at Boot
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=forking
User=root
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/start_sybase_sap.sh
Restart=no
TimeoutSec=600

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

5. Enabling the Service

Run the following commands:

chmod +x /usr/local/bin/start_sybase_sap.sh
sudo systemctl daemon-reexec
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable sybase_sap_start.service
sudo systemctl start sybase_sap_start.service
sudo systemctl status sybase_sap_start.service

6. Monitoring and Logs

  • Startup Logs: /usr/sap/start_sybase_sap.log

  • Logs contain timestamped entries for each step — useful for debugging in case of startup issues.

7. Benefits of This Setup

  • Zero manual intervention after VM boot
  • Correct sequence — Sybase DB starts before SAP
  • Detailed logging for troubleshooting

Conclusion

With this configuration, both Sybase database and SAP application automatically start after a VM reboot on GCP. The approach ensures reliability, reduces human error, and speeds up system availability.

Regards,

Nitin Khose

entry.title: SBPA Process Scheduler Trigger : A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Welcome back to our SAP Build Process Automation series! In this third blog, we'll dive deep into one of the most crucial aspects of process automation: how to automatically start business processes using scheduler. 

What Are Scheduled Triggers?

Scheduled triggers enable you to automate the initiation of business processes at predefined intervals, eliminating the need for manual intervention or dependency on external events. By defining a time-based schedule, you can ensure that processes run exactly when you want them to, whether that’s daily, weekly, monthly, or following a custom recurrence pattern.

Key Benefits:

  • Hands-free automation – Processes start automatically without user action.
  • Enhanced efficiency – Streamlines operations by reducing delays and human error.
  • Lower manual workload – Frees up resources for higher-value activities.
  • Consistent execution – Ensures tasks run on time, every time.
  • Flexible scheduling – Supports a wide range of recurrence patterns to suit business needs.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  1. Access to SAP Build Process Automation
  2. A working process (we'll use the vendor invoice validation approval process project from previous episodes)
  3. BTP Cockpit access for service key retrieval - trial cockpit

Step-by-Step Implementation 

Phase 1: Project Setup

Step 1: Create a Copy of Your Existing Project from previous blog

  1. Navigate to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Locate your existing project (e.g., "Invoice Validation Approval Process Form")
  3. Select the project by clicking on it
  4. Click "Save As" to create a copy
  5. Enter new project details: 
    1. Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduler 
    2. Description: A invoice validation and approval process scheduler
  6. Click "Save" to create the new project   

Step 2: Access and Prepare the Process

  1. Open the newly created project
  2. Navigate to the process section
  3. You should see:
    • Four forms
    • One process
    •  Existing form scheduler (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)

Phase 2: Removing Existing Process and Adding Scheduled Trigger

Step 3: Remove the Existing Form Process and add the scheduled trigger

  1. Click on the existing form process (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)
  2. Click "Remove" to delete the form
  3. You'll now see a block asking "How do you want to start your process?"
  4. Click "Add a scheduled trigger

Step 4: Create the Scheduled Trigger

  1. Click on "Scheduled Trigger"
  2. Save the process (mandatory before creating Scheduled trigger)
    • Click the Save button
  3. Configure Scheduled Trigger Details: 
    • Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger 
    • Identifier: [Auto-generated - do not modify]
  4. Click "Create"
  5. You'll see a success message: "Scheduled trigger created successfully"  

Phase 3: Configure the Process Inputs

Step 5: Examine Scheduler Trigger Properties

  1. Click on the Scheduler trigger you just created
  2. Review Output Fields:
  • These are automatically synchronized from process inputs
  • Fields include: Vendor Name, Invoice Number, Invoice Date, Vendor Email, Invoice Amount, Due Date

Phase 4: Project Release and Deployment 

Step 6: Release the Project

  1. Save all changes
  2. Click "Release" button in the top toolbar
  3. Confirm the release when prompted
  4. Wait for successful release message

Click on the "Release" button, add the release notes (Optional) and click on the Release.

Step 7: Deploy the Project

  1. Click "Deploy" button (appears after release)
  2. Select target environment (typically "Public Environment")
  3. Confirm deployment
  4. Wait for deployment completion
  5. Note the deployment success message

Phase 5: Accessing Deployment Information 

Step 8: Navigate to Control Tower

  1. Go to SAP Build Lobby home
  2. Click on "Control Tower"
  3. Navigate to "Tenant Configuration"
  4. Click on "Environments"
  5. Select "Public Environment" (or your deployment target)

Step 9: Locate Your Deployed Project

  1. Find your project: "Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger"
  2. Click on the project name
  3. Navigate to "Triggers" tab
  4. Locate: "Invoice Validation Approval Process Scheduled Trigger"

Phase 6: Configure the Scheduled Trigger

Step 10: Activate the Trigger

  1. Click on the three dots under Actions
  2. Select "Activate"

Step 11: Schedule Configuration

  1. Schedule Tab Settings
    1. Date Range: August 14th, 2025 to August 25th, 2026 (1-month subscription)
    2. Time Zone: IST (Indian Standard Time)
    3. Recurrence: 5 month (monthly execution)
    4. Start Time: 9:43 MM
    5. Day Number: 1st day of every month
  2. Recurrence Options Available
    1. Minutes: Maximum 59 minutes
    2. Hours: Maximum 24 hours
    3. Days: Maximum 7 days
    4. Weeks: Maximum 35 weeks
    5. Months: Maximum 12 months

Step 12: Input Parameters

  1. Configure Input Data
    1. Switch to "Input Parameter" tab
    2. Enter the following sample data:
      1. Vendor Name
      2. Invoice Number
      3. Invoice Date
      4. Vendor Email
      5. Invoice Amount
      6. Due Date
  2. Activate Configuration
    1. Click "Activate"
    2. The trigger will be successfully updated

Phase 7: Testing and Monitoring

Step 13: Test Immediate Execution

  • After activation, you'll see new options under "Actions":
    • Disable trigger
    • Run now (for testing)
    • Edit trigger configuration
  • Click "Run now" for testing

Step 14: Monitor Process Instance

  1. Return to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to "Monitoring"
  3. Click "Process and Workflow Instances"
  4. Locate your new process instance:
    • Status: Running
    • Instance ID: [Auto-generated]
    • Started by: Scheduled Trigger

Step 15: Review Process Data

  1. Click on the process instance
  2. Review "Process Details":
    • Vendor Name: TEST VENDOR
    • Invoice Number: 1234
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Vendor Email: test-vendor@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-16

    3. Check process flow: Should be waiting for approval

Step 16: Review all the details and Approve the process form

Step 17: Verify Process Completion

  1. Return to "Process and Workflow Instances"
  2. Refresh the page
  3. Check your process instance:
    • Status: Completed
    • All approval messages visible
    • Complete process flow executed 

Conclusion

Scheduled triggers in SAP Build Process Automation offer a robust and flexible way to automate recurring business processes without manual intervention.

Through the vendor invoice validation approval prcess example, we see how such triggers can streamline operations, maintain consistency, and enhance efficiency by executing workflows at precise intervals. By carefully configuring schedules, input parameters, and approval steps, organizations can reduce errors, optimize resources, and scale their automation efforts.

However, success depends on thorough testing, proper security measures, and continuous monitoring to ensure reliability and performance in production environments.

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation - Automation does not complete/finish
entry.content:
Dear community,

i sat up an workflow in SAP Build Process Automation. The trigger is a pretty basic formular which i need to submit. After that, my automation starts. But here is the problem: the automation starts, executes properly but never comes to finish.

Furthermore, the output parameter of the automation is filled properly, available in the workflow but cant be used due to the fact that the automation is never stopping/completed or somehow finished. In the screenshots below and attached to this question i provided details about this issue. What can i do that the automation comes to an end?

The automation itself works in the tests without any issue and all the values are correctly parsed and mapped. It just doesn't continue as you can see in the screenshots and therefore no further steps in the workflow are executed.

Here are further screenshots additionally to the screenshots in the attachments:

entry.title: How to Specify SAP DMS Repository for Different Projects in SAP Build Process Automation?
entry.content:
Hi Community,

We’ve integrated SAP Document Management Service (DMS) with SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) by creating a destination in our BTP subaccount. After this setup, BPA forms started showing the option to upload documents, and the files are getting stored in DMS.

In our destination configuration, we specified a repository ID, and all uploaded documents are automatically saved in that specific repository. BPA is even organizing the documents by creating a dedicated folder for each form submission, which is great.

However, here’s the challenge:

We have multiple projects in BPA within the same subaccount, and we’d like to use different repositories for different projects. But currently, I don’t see any way in BPA to specify or override the repository per project or per form.

Is there a way to specify the DMS repository that a particular BPA project or process should use for file uploads?
If not directly in BPA, is there any workaround or recommendation?

Any insights or best practices would be appreciated!

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation: Test Automation vs Attended Agent Execution
entry.content:
Hello!

I am learning SAP Build Process Automation and have hit an issue I can't seem to find details about online. Hoping someone here can help.

Context:

I have designed a simple automation that does the following:

1. Ask User to Enter in a Value using Input Dialog.

2. Create a New Section in OneNote.

3. Rename Section in OneNote (using Text from Input Dialog).

4. Rename Page in the Section.

5. Add a new Page to the Section.

6. Rename the new Page in the Section, after waiting for 2000ms.

Problem:

When I execute this automation in test mode in the Automation Editor, it works perfectly. When I execute the released version using my Attended Mode Agent, I get the Input Dialog, then the Automation Fails with the following error: "Timeout error: Waiting for screen(s) [Name of Automation Screen] to appear (30 s)."

Why is my test of the automation able to find the screen and execute the automation, but the Attended Agent execution is not able to find the screen and complete the automation.

This is all occurring on my personal desktop. I have not changed the applications open/available between Attended Agent failure and Test Mode success. I can literally run Attended and Test mode back to back repeatedly, and Attended Mode fails, and Test Mode works; every time.

Thank you in advance for any advice.

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation - Number of processes / comparision to others
entry.content:
Hi community,

perhaps this is a uncommon question, but I would like to know whether we are a "big player" or a "small light" in the SAP Build Process Automation community.

Here is our setup:

- 2 developers (only some hours during the week)

- 87 projects in the build lobby

- 628 automation runs in month July / around 20 automations a day

- Started in 2021 (with iRPA)

Thanks to everyone who participates.

Best Regards

Mathias

entry.title: Moving Gmail Inbox Emails to Subfolders Using Message ID in SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content: Hi  Everyone , I am currently working with SAP Build Process Automation on a use case where I need to manage Gmail emails. The requirement is to identify an email in the Inbox using the unique Message ID provided by Gmail and then move this email from the Inbox to a custom subfolder within the Inbox. I have tried using the Move Email (Online) activity, but I am facing challenges as the activity does not seem to recognize the custom subfolder, and the process fails when I attempt to move the email using the Message ID. I would like to know the recommended approach for fetching Gmail emails based on Message ID and the correct way to configure the target folder path when moving emails into subfolders or labels. Any guidance, best practices, or configuration examples from the community would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: SAP Build Issues with S/4 HANA Attachments for Controlling Documents
entry.content:
Hello,

We've found a potential bug with the SAP Build attachments process with S/4 HANA (version 2020).  When we use the POST AttachmentContentSet method for accounting documents (BusinessObjectType = BKPF) we are able to see the attachments after the process runs.  We check them in SAP GUI or Fiori.  

However, when we attempt to use the same method with FIN Controlling documents (BusinessObjectType = BUS2072), we are only able to see the attachments in SAP GUI or Fiori if someone creates an attachment through the GUI or Fiori first.  If no attachment is created through the GUI or Fiori, the attachments created by SAP Build through the POST AttachmentContentSet method are not visible in the GUI or Fiori.

MS Copilot reports that this is because there is no BINARY_RELATION_CREATE_COMMIT with BusinessObjectType = BUS2072, but there is with BusinessObjectType = BKPF.  While I cannot confirm this, I was hoping an expert in the community might be able to confirm if this is a bug?

entry.title: Build Process automation approval form request isn’t showing up in the Workzone My Inbox
entry.content:
In SAP Build Process Automation (Standard subscription), the approval form requests aren’t showing up in the Workzone My Inbox for new business users. However, it’s working fine for the three older business users. I’ve checked, and both new and old users have the same roles assigned, so I’m not sure what’s causing the difference.

Do we need to map CIS business users somewhere in the tenant configuration or make any additional setup for new users?

Would really appreciate your insights on this issue to resolve it.

#WorkzoneInbox
#ApprovalFormIssue
#BusinessUserMapping
